claim: If you put on one ring, a ring will be on your finger.

supporting.text: Placing a ring on a finger involves the physical act of sliding the ring onto the finger, resulting in the ring being worn.

attacks.text: Placing a ring on a finger involves the physical act of sliding the ring onto the finger, resulting in the ring being worn.
If the finger is missing or amputated, placing a ring on it is impossible, so the ring will not be on the finger.
Prosthetic fingers or attachments can still allow a ring to be worn, even if the biological finger is missing.
If the ring is too large or too small, it may fall off or not fit properly, meaning it is not securely on the finger.
Ring sizing ensures most rings fit properly, making ill-fitting rings a rare exception.

supporting.text: A ring is designed to encircle a finger when worn, fulfilling its intended function.

attacks.text: A ring is designed to encircle a finger when worn, fulfilling its intended function.
Some rings, such as toe rings or nose rings, are not designed for fingers.
The claim specifies 'a ring on your finger,' so non-finger rings are irrelevant.
A ring may be too large or too small to stay on the finger when worn.
Properly sized rings, as implied by 'put on,' will stay on the finger.

supporting.text: The definition of 'putting on a ring' implies that the ring is now located on the finger.

attacks.text: The definition of 'putting on a ring' implies that the ring is now located on the finger.
The ring may not fit the finger, preventing it from being properly placed on the finger.
Standard rings are designed to fit most fingers, making ill-fitting rings a rare exception.
The act of putting on a ring could be interrupted (e.g., dropping it) before it reaches the finger.
Interruptions during the act of putting on a ring are uncommon in normal circumstances.
The term 'finger' could be ambiguous (e.g., artificial fingers or symbolic gestures).
In common usage, 'finger' refers to a natural human finger unless specified otherwise.

supporting.text: Human anatomy allows fingers to accommodate rings when they are placed onto them.

attacks.text: Human anatomy allows fingers to accommodate rings when they are placed onto them.
Some individuals have missing or deformed fingers, making it impossible to wear rings.
Prosthetic or reconstructed fingers can still accommodate rings in many cases.
Rings may not fit due to swelling, injury, or medical conditions like arthritis.
Adjustable or flexible rings can still be worn in such cases.
